text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 90B06 supply chain scheduling; semi-online algorithm; competitive analysis serial article Averbakh, Igor; Baysan, Mehmet Number: 6109929 Batching and delivery in semi-online distribution systems. 2013 Summary: Suppose a distribution center receives orders from customers for delivery of some goods. Orders may be delayed to be grouped and delivered in batches. The cost of one delivery does not depend on the number of orders taken. The total cost (to be minimized) is the sum of the total delay time of the orders and the total delivery cost. In the on-line environment, where at any time there is no information about future orders, there is a simple on-line algorithm with competitive ratio 2 which is known to be the best possible. We consider the semi-online environment where at any instant we know the orders that will be released in the next S time units, but have no information about the orders that will be released later. For this environment, we present a semi-online algorithm and analyze its competitive ratio.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 34N05 34B24 time scale; even order Sturm – Liouville dynamic equation; time reversed symplectic system; quadratic functional serial article Zemánek, Petr Number: 6107010 A note on the equivalence between even order Sturm-Liouville equations and symplectic systems on time scales. 2013 Summary: The math1 th-order Sturm – Liouville differential and difference equations can be written as linear Hamiltonian differential systems and symplectic difference systems, respectively. In this work, a similar result is given for the math2 th-order Sturm – Liouville equation on time scales using time reversed symplectic dynamic systems. Moreover, we show that this transformation preserves the value of the corresponding quadratic functionals which enables a further generalization of the theory for continuous and discrete Sturm – Liouville equations.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C20 05C40 05C10 digraph; directional antennae; plane graph; sensors; cut edges; spanner; stretch factor; strongly connected subgraps; edge orientation; number of oriented arcs serial article Kranakis, Evangelos; Morales, Oscar; Stacho, Ladislav Number: 1254.05068 Strongly connected orientations of plane graphs. 2013 The purpose of the paper is to orient a subset of edges of a given plane graph such that the resulting subgraph is strongly connected and spans all vertices of the graph. In addition, the number of oriented arcs is minimum and at the same time produces a digraph with smallest possible stretch factor. The paper also presents three constructions for such orientations.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 05C07 05C38 05C35 Randić index; girth; bound serial article Liang, Meili; Liu, Bolian Number: 1254.05041 On the Randić index and girth of graphs. 2013 Summary: The Randić index math1 of a graph math2 is defined by math3 , where math4 is the degree of a vertex math5 in math6 and the summation extends over all edges math7 of math8 . In this work, we give a sharp upper bound and a lower bound of the Randić index among connected math9 -vertex graphs with girth math10 .

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 65R20 error estimation; homotopy perturbation method; Volterra-Fredholm integral equations; convergence; series solution serial article Hetmaniok, Edyta; Nowak, Iwona; Słota, Damian; Wituła, Roman Number: 6107017 A study of the convergence of and error estimation for the homotopy perturbation method for the Volterra-Fredholm integral equations. 2013 Summary: The solution of the Volterra-Fredholm integral equations of the second kind is presented. The proposed method is based on the homotopy perturbation method, which consists in constructing the series whose sum is the solution of the problem considered. The problem of the convergence of the series constructed is formulated and a proof of the formulation is given in the work. Additionally, the estimation of the approximate solution errors obtained by taking the partial sums of the series is elaborated on.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="\log" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">log</m:mi><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:log xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1"/></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">\log</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 91 portfolio optimization; default risk; stochastic factor; HJB equation; sub-super solution serial article Bo, Lijun; Wang, Yongjin; Yang, Xuewei Number: 6109973 Stochastic portfolio optimization with default risk. 2013 Summary: A stochastic portfolio optimization problem with default risk on an infinite time horizon is investigated. The default risk premium and the default intensity corresponding to the defaultable bond are assumed to rely on a stochastic factor formulated by a diffusion process. We study the optimal allocation and consumption policies to maximize the infinite horizon expected discounted non- math1 HARA utility of the consumption, and we use the dynamic programming principle to derive the Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) equation. Then we explore the HJB equation by employing a so-called sub-super solution approach. The optimal allocation and consumption policies are finally presented in a verification theorem, and also a numerical simulation is given at the end of the paper.

html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 34K60 34K50 34K20 92D25 delays; stochastic perturbations; global asymptotic stability serial article Huang, Yong; Liu, Qun; Liu, Yiliang Number: 6107019 Global asymptotic stability of a general stochastic Lotka-Volterra system with delays. 2013 Summary: This paper discusses a general stochastic Lotka-Volterra system with delays. Some conditions for the global asymptotic stability are established.

math.1: <m:math xmlns="http://zentralblatt.org" alttext="L^{2}" xml:id="m1.1" display="inline" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:semantics xml:id="m1.1a" xref="m1.1.cmml"><m:msup xml:id="m1.1.3" xref="m1.1.3.cmml"><m:mi xml:id="m1.1.1" xref="m1.1.1.cmml">L</m:mi><m:mn xml:id="m1.1.2.1" xref="m1.1.2.1.cmml">2</m:mn></m:msup><m:annotation-xml xml:id="m1.1.cmml" encoding="MathML-Content" xref="m1.1"><m:apply xml:id="m1.1.3.cmml" xref="m1.1.3"><m:csymbol cd="ambiguous" xml:id="m1.1.3.1.cmml">superscript</m:csymbol><m:ci xml:id="m1.1.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.1">L</m:ci><m:cn type="integer" xml:id="m1.1.2.1.cmml" xref="m1.1.2.1">2</m:cn></m:apply></m:annotation-xml><m:annotation xml:id="m1.1b" encoding="application/x-tex" xref="m1.1.cmml">L^{2}</m:annotation></m:semantics></m:math>

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 45B05 Toeplitz and Hankel kernel; Hartley transform; convolution serial article Anh, Pham Ky; Tuan, Nguyen Minh; Tuan, Phan Duc Number: 6109980 The finite Hartley new convolutions and solvability of the integral equations with Toeplitz plus Hankel kernels. 2013 In this article, integral equations of convolution type with a sum of a Toeplitz and a Hankel kernel are considered. The authors construct eight new generalized convolutions for the finite Hartley transforms. Additionally, they obtain both a necessary and sufficient condition for the unique solvability in math1 . Note that this solvability condition is different from Tsitsiklis and Levy due to the convolution approach.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 81-02 81P45 81P68 book Bagarello, Fabio Number: 6110091 Quantum dynamics for classical systems. With applications of the number operator. 2013 Preliminary review / Publisher’s description: Mathematics is increasingly applied to classical problems in finance, biology, economics, and elsewhere. Quantum Dynamics for Classical Systems describes how quantum toolsâthe number operator in particularâcan be used to create dynamical systems in which the variables are operator-valued functions and whose results explain the presented model. The book presents mathematical results and their applications to concrete systems and discusses the methods used, results obtained, and techniques developed for the proofs of the results. The central ideas of number operators are illuminated while avoiding excessive technicalities that are unnecessary for understanding and learning the various mathematical applications. The presented dynamical systems address a variety of contexts and offer clear analyses and explanations of concluded results. Additional features in Quantum Dynamics for Classical Systems include: math1 Applications across diverse fields including stock markets and population migration as well as a unique quantum perspective on these classes of models; math2 Illustrations of the use of creation and annihilation operators for classical problems; math3 Examples of the recent increase in research and literature on the many applications of quantum tools in applied mathematics; math4 Clarification on numerous misunderstandings and misnomers while shedding light on new approaches in the field. Quantum Dynamics for Classical Systems is an ideal reference for researchers, professionals, and academics in applied mathematics, economics, physics, biology, and sociology. The book is also excellent for courses in dynamical systems, quantum mechanics, and mathematical models.

text: html{border: 0px #006699 solid;border-left-width: 15px} body {margin: 15px;padding: 0px;background-color:#ffffff;color:black; font-family:helvetica;font-size: 14px;line-height: 1.4em} div.volume-title {font-size:24pt;text-align:center;font-weight:bold} div.title {font-style:italic;font-weight:bold} div.mathics {font-size:larger;font-weight:bold} span.mathics-zbl {float:right} div.matverw {font-size:smaller} div.review {margin:5mm 5mm 5mm 5mm} div.aunot {font-weight:bold} div.published {font-weight:bold} .number {font-style: italic; text-align:right} div.reviewer{font-style:italic;text-align:right} EN 35K05 35B40 35B35 asymptotic behavior; parabolic equation; perturbation; spectral splitting serial article Langer, Mikael; Kozlov, Vladimir Number: 6109974 Asymptotics of solutions of a perturbed heat equation. 2013 Summary: We consider the Neumann problem for the heat equation perturbed by a dissipation term math1 , where math2 is a function of space and time variables, small in some integral sense, and math3 is the temperature. We derive a two term asymptotic representation for the solution for large time which can be used, in particular, to study boundedness and stability properties of the solution in the case when the leading term of the asymptotic expansion does not allow to do this analysis.
